I20051117

- I changed the target platform to be N20051118
- When I tried to launch the JUnit test, it failed with the following errors:

It appears as though new plug-ins have been added the last day or so.

I suspect the Plug-ins tab of your launch configuration uses the second option 
(ie. a hand-picked set of plug-ins).  In which case, press 'Add Required Plug-
ins' and relaunch.

If your launch configuration was using the first option (ie. first radio 
button on the Plugins tab), things would have been fine.

That's one drawback of the hand-picked list of plug-ins.

Is that the case here?

jeff, all existing RCP launch configurations that are pre-
letsbreakuptheruntime will be broken now, since their list of plug-ins to run 
is hardcoded.

PDE may need to do something here (e.g. an under-the-cover one-time migration 
of existing launch configs that use the hand-picked plug-in option).  We could 
then set a flag on the launch configuration so that PDE does not mess with it 
again.  Thoughts?

(In reply to comment #1)
> I suspect the Plug-ins tab of your launch configuration uses the second option 
> (ie. a hand-picked set of plug-ins).  In which case, press 'Add Required Plug-
> ins' and relaunch.
Actually I'm using the first option.

are the new plug-ins (eg. org.eclipse.core.jobs, org.eclipse.equinox.common, 
etc.) selected on your target platform preference page?

Here are steps to reproduce so that you can see it by yourself:
1. Start a plain I20051116 on a new empty workspace
2. Create a new 'Eclipse Application' launch config and run it
3. Exit the runtime workspace
4. Preferences > Plug-in Development > Target Platfrome
5. Change the location to point to N20051118
6. Attempt to run the launch config created in 2
Observe: You get the error reported above.

Sorry, I think this problem is caused by the runtime split work.

A bit of background: we are currently working on a runtime split and were testing the new code in the test builds. 

However, several nightly builds from the last week run using the new code - and we didn't realize this until this weekend. At this point we are considering our options for the next build.

The split runtime adds several new plugins that have to be specified on the osgi.bundles property in the config.ini:

osgi.bundles=org.eclipse.equinox.common@2:start, org.eclipse.core.jobs@2:start, org.eclipse.equinox.registry@2:start, org.eclipse.equinox.preferences, org.eclipse.core.contenttype, org.eclipse.core.runtime@2:start, org.eclipse.update.configurator@3:start

If you'd like to use those builds for debug or run purposes, the config.ini file used by the debug / run configurations have to be manually adjusted.

To do this, create a simple project in your workspace (let's call it "Configuration") and copy the config.ini file from your new install (eclipse\configuration\config.ini). If this is the nightly build affected by this problem, it will have the osgi.bundles line set to the value above.

Next, go into "Debug..." or "Run..." menu and select the configuration you are trying to run. Switch to "Configuration" tab, select "Use an existing config.ini as a template", and specify the file you just copied above.

You'll need to repeat this for all configurations you are going to Debug or Run.

Again, sorry, this code should not have been in the nightly builds.

Thanks for the explanation. I was indeed trying to debug a test that failed in N20051118. Since then it appears that the test is now passing, so I guess I won't need this trick. 

I just wanted to make sure that someone in PDE land was aware of a potential bad problem. Please the problem is under control.
thanks Jerome.  You helped us avoid a disastrous I-build.

Fixed.

If the target platform contains the refactored runtime, we now generate a different config.ini.

All existing launch configurations will be automatically and trasparently migrated the first time they are launched.  The launch configuration will be marked with a pde.version=3.2 attribute so that the migration occurs only once.
